Manifesto for Agile Software Development

Authors: Kent Beck, James Grenning, Robert C. Martin,
Mike Beedle, Jim Highsmith, Steve Mellor,
Arie van Bennekum, Andrew Hunt, Ken Schwaber,
Alistair Cockburn, Ron Jeffries, Jeff Sutherland,
Ward Cunningham, Jon Kern, Dave Thomas,
Martin Fowler, and Brian Marick
Reviewers: Lili Xu, Yang Lou

The Manifesto for Agile Software Development was created by seventeen software developers in 2001. The Agile Manifesto expressed four key values and twelve principles of Agile software development. Based on the values and principles stated in the Agile Manifesto, Agile software development utilizes the iterative approach that delivers new pieces of the application more often and provides greater fiexibility than the waterfall approach.

The highest priority is for customer. As we see in the manifesto, the agile development delivers the new versions as soon as possible. In this case, the products can be quickly updated and upgraded to meet the customers' needs. Meanwhile, Pushing the changes quickly for the products also gather customers' feedback soon and is of great help for the products.

Changing requirements is welcome in agile development. Since agile devolvement iterates fast. Changing requirements allow the developers reacts quickly to customers' needs, which not only improves the feedback, but also the product quality. Shorter timescale are perferred. As in small batch work, the defects and problems can be easily detected and resolved early. It also helps the developers to identify the problems precisely.

One of the principles is business people and developers must work together daily. The communication is of great importance in devops, as listed above, the requirments are changing and highest pirority is for customer, working together helps the developers quickly notice the requirment change and react.

The first core value of the Agile Manifesto

The first key value of the Agile Manifesto is to value people over process. If one company value processes and tools, the processes are on average more clear but processes will be gradually out-of-date due to the lack of updates. New processes and tools are created by humans. In a human-centric company, the improvement in processes and tools increases productivity.

The second core value of the Agile Manifesto

The second key value shows that working software is more important than comprehensive documentation. As stated in the principle, working software is the primary way to measure the progress. In that case, a working software is more persuading than documentation. The teammates are more likely to honor your progress by the working software instead of the documentation. However, the documentation can be the resource that assists the understanding.

As said in above, in order to show the progress, the quick delivery of the working software helps. The shorter timescale informs others the progress and improves the communication. It also reduces the work of detailed documentation because some work are self-explaining, which is more smoothly than the detailed documentation.

The third core value of the Agile Manifesto

The third key value of the Agile Manifesto is to focus on collaboration between development team and customer, instead of emphasizing negotiation. Collaboration will produce more valuable product since the customer is involved to provide helpful feedbacks to increase values of the product during the sprint review. In addition, technologies and customer's needs are rapidly changing, hence it's hard to determine all the details of the product at the very beginning. By collaborating, the development team can integrate needed changes with existing product smoothly.

The fourth core value of the Agile Manifesto

The fourth key value of the Agile Manifesto is that reacting to change is superior to up-front planning. It's not viable to make a detailed plan in advance if the project context is constantly changing and less information is available at the present time. Feedbacks from the customer might demand project plan changes as well. What's more, delivering maximum value to the customer which might result in plan changes is more important than simply following a plan.
